div.l: But if he wolde be slayn̄ of Symkyn̄
With panade or wᵗith knyfe or bodekyn̄
For Ielous folk ben̄ perlouse eủer moo
Algates they wolde her͗e wyves wende soo
And eke for she was somdel smoterlysh
She was as digne as water in a dyssh
And full of oker and of bysmare
Hir thought þat a lady shuld hir spare
What for hir kynrede and for hir nortelrye
That she had lerned in the noneryrenoneryrenonery
A dout̉er had they by twix them twoo
Of twenty yeer with outen eny moo
Sauyng a childe þat was of half yeer age
In cradel it lay and was a ꝓpropre page
This wenche thykke and weel y growen̄ was
With camoys nose and eyen̄ grey as glas
With buttokys brode and breestys rounde and hygh
But right faire was hir here I wole nat lye
The ꝑperson̄ of þe toun̄ for she was so feyre
In purpos was to make hir hise heyre
Bothe of his catel and of his Mesuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpos was to bistowe hir hye
In to som worthy bloode of Auncetrye
For holy cherche good mot been dispended
On holy Chirche blood þat is descended
Therfor͗e he wold his holy blood honoure
Though þat the holy Chirche shuld deuoure
Gret soken hath this myll̉ere out of doute
With whete and malte of the lande a boute
And nameliche there was a gret college
Men clepe it the soler halle of Cāmmbrigge
Ther͗e was her whete and eke ther malte y groıı̄unde
And on a day it happed on a stounde
Seke lay the manciple on a maladye
Men wenden wysely that he shuld deye
For whiche this Miller stale both mele and corne
An hundred tyme more thanne by forne
For ther͗e by forne he stale but curteslye
But now he was a theef outrageouslye
For whiche þe wardeyn chidde and made gret fare
But therof set nat þe myller nout a tare
He craked booste and swore it was nat soo
Thanne were yong scolers twoo
That duelled in the halle of whiche I yow seye

they were and lusty for to pleye Testife pr Since space is left for the first word—"Testyff" in Mm—its omission is apparently deliberate. This the first of the collations to Urry by (presumably) Martin, indicated by "pr[inted]" here and throughout.
And onely for her m̉erthe and reủerye revelry pr
Vpon the wardeyn̄ besely they crye
To geve hem leve but a litel stounde
To go to the mylle and seen̄ her corn y grounde
And hardely they durst helde her nekke
The myller shuld nat stele them half a pekke
Of corne ne by force ne by sleight hem reve
And at the laste the warden gaf hem leve
Iohn hight the one and Aleyn hight the other
Of one towne were they borne þat hight Strother
Fer in the north I can nat telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy all his geere
And on an hors the sak he cast a none
Forth goth Aleyn the clerk and also Iohn
With good swerde and bokeler by his side
Iohn knewe the weye hym neded no guyde
And at the mylle the sak a doun he leyth
Aleyn spake first all heil Symon in feith
How fares thy fair͗e douter and thy wyfe
Aleyn welcome qᵈuod Symkyn̄ by my lyfe
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
By god Symond qᵈuod Iohn nede hath no pere
Hym byhoves ʆserue hym self þat hath no swayne
Or elles he is a fole as Clerkes seyne
Our͗e manciple I hope wole be dede
So werkes hym ay the wanges in his hed
And therfore am I comen and eke Aleyn̄
To grynde our͗e corne and cary it hom ageyn̄
I pray yow spede vs hens in all þat ye may
It shal be done qᵈuod Symkyn by my fay
What wole ye done while þat it is in hande
By god right by the hoper wole I stande
Qᵈuod Iohn and se how gates the corne gaas ynne
Yet saw I neủere by my fader kynne
How þat the hoper wagges tyll and froo
Aleyn answered wilt thow soo
Thanne wole I be bynethe by my crowne
And see how gates the mylle falles downe
In till the trogh þat shal be my disporte
Qᵈuod Iohn in faith I may ben one of yoᵘure sorte
I is as euel a myller as arn yee
This Miller smyled of ther nycete
